issues.text: Whether s. 15 of the Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947, and Rule 80 framed under the Act were ultra vires, being a breach of Art. 286(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: the High Court held that s. 15 of the Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947, and Rule 80 framed under the Act were ultra vires, being a breach of Art. 286 2  of the Constitution. The High Court granted a certificate under Art. 132 1  of the

issues.text: Whether the amendment and the Rule had the effect of taxing sales in the course of inter-State trade or commerce and were therefore illegal

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld his contention about Art. 286 2 . In the High Court, separate judgments were delivered by the learned Chief Justice and Ram Labhaya, J. They both agreed that s. 15, as amended, and the Rule were ultra vires Art. 286 2 . The reasons given by the learned Judges were different. According to the Chief Justice, the amendment and the Rule had the effect of taxing sales in the course of inter-State trade or commerce and were, therefore, illegal.

issues.text: Whether though by s. 3 sales in the course of inter-State trade or commerce were excluded from the ambit of the Act, this section remained only a pious declaration because its effect was not incorporated in the machinery section s. 15 leading to taxation of such sales

anchor.surface_text: Ram Labhaya, J., held that the sale to R. C. Dey and the sale by him in Calcutta were separate sales, and that the first sale was not in the course of inter-State trade or commerce, and was taxable. He, however, held that though by s. 3, which is the charging section, sales in the course of inter-State trade or commerce were excluded from the ambit of the Act, this section remained only a pious declaration, because its effect was not incorporated in the machinery section, namely, s. 15.

issues.text: Whether the transactions of sales taxed were in the course of inter-State trade or commerce under Art. 286(2)

anchor.surface_text: The transactions of sales which have been taxed were wholly inside the State of Orissa. They were sales by persons in the State of Orissa to persons within the State of Orissa of goods which were in Orissa. The fact that the purchaser sold those very goods to dealers outside the State is not relevant, as those sales are distinct and separate from the sales on which the taxes in question have been imposed.

issues.text: Whether it is an error to think that because the machinery section s. 15 does not repeat the exemption given by the charging section, the net turnover would necessarily include sales in the course of inter-State trade or commerce

anchor.surface_text: the operation of the charging section, the turnover of a dealer would necessarily include the sales in the course of inter-State trade or commerce. Even if the net turnover did, so include such sales, the dealer would, under sub-s. (1A) of s. 3, be able to claim that those transactions were not taxable, because they fell within the ban of Art. 286(2) as well as s. 3(1A) of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the amendment and the Rule offended against Art. 286(2) and Part XIII of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: challenging the amendment and the Rule, and contended that they offended against Art. 286 2  and Part XIII of the Constitution, and were thus ultra vires. He also submitted that the amendment and the Rules were void as offending Art. 19 1 g . The last submission was given up in the High Court,

issues.text: Whether the amendment and the Rules were void as offending Art. 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: and were thus ultra vires. He also submitted that the amendment and the Rules were void as offending Art. 19 1 g . The last submission was given up in the High Court, and the objection about Part XIII of the Constitution, which was decided against him, must be taken to have been abandoned,

holdings.text: These observations are entirely applicable in the context of the facts, as are to be found in this appeal. Indeed, all that is necessary to apply the above passage to the facts of this case is to substitute Assam in the place of Orissa. In our opinion, this point must be held to be concluded against the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: These observations are entirely applicable in the context of the facts, as are to be found in this appeal. Indeed, all that is necessary to apply the above passage to the facts of this case is to substitute Assam in the place of Orissa.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly applies precedent from Endupuri Narasimham Son v. State of Orissa holding that intra-state sales to local dealers are not inter-state even if resold outside.

holdings.text: The introduction of sub-s. (1A) did nothing more than repeat in the Act the prohibition contained in Art. 286.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charging section s.3(1A) incorporates constitutional prohibition of Art. 286, excluding inter-state sales from tax liability.

holdings.text: It is an error to think that because the machinery section, namely, s. 15, does not repeat the exemption given by the charging section, the turnover of a dealer would necessarily include the sales in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.

anchor.surface_text: It is an error to think that because the machinery section, namely, s. 15, does not repeat the exemption given by the charging section, the turnover of a dealer would necessarily include the sales in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Machinery provisions for net turnover calculation need not replicate charging section exclusions; constitutional and charging bans apply independently.

holdings.text: What s. 15 does, is to grant an additional exemption in respect of sales in which the goods, though sold to a registered dealer, are meant for resale in the State, itself.

anchor.surface_text: What s. 15 does, is to grant an additional exemption in respect of sales in which the goods, though sold to a registered dealer, are meant for resale in the State, itself. It is quite easy to see that unless this exemption was granted,

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.15 provides intra-state resale deduction to prevent multiple taxation within state, valid as it operates only on taxable intra-state sales.

holdings.text: Sub-section (1A) has the added support of Art. 286, and the Constitution must prevail.

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made to sub-s.  2  of s. 3, and it was said that sub-s.  2  stated that every dealer to whom sub-s.  1  did not apply, shall be liable to be taxed under this Act, and that there was no mention of subs.  1 A there.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.3(1A) must be read harmoniously with other subsections; Art. 286 ensures inter-state sales exclusion prevails over any textual omission.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the appeal must succeed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the appeal must succeed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in holding s.15 (as amended) and Rule 80 ultra vires Art. 286(2); provisions valid as they tax only intra-state sales.
